title: Psalm 136
text:
Psalm 136 is the 136th <a href="psalm">psalm</a> of the <a href="Bible">biblical</a> <a href="Book%20of%20Psalms">Book of Psalms</a>. In the slightly different numbering system in the Greek <a href="Septuagint">Septuagint</a> version of the Bible, and in its Latin translation, the <a href="Vulgate">Vulgate</a>, this psalm is Psalm 135. It is sometimes referred to as "The Great Hallel". 
Uses.
Judaism.
The term Great <a href="Hallel">Hallel</a> (), meaning "great praise", is used to refer to Psalm 136. It is called "great" to differentiate it from the <a href="Egyptian%20Hallel">Egyptian Hallel</a>, another prayer of praise comprising psalms 113 to 118. In the Talmud, opinions vary whether Great Hallel includes only Psalm 136, or else chapters 135-136, or else chapters 134-136; the accepted opinion is that it only includes 136.
Verse 1,
was recited at <a href="Solomon">Solomon</a>'s dedication of the <a href="Solomon%27s%20Temple">Temple</a>; <a href="Charles%20Spurgeon">Charles Spurgeon</a> suggests that the whole psalm was sung.
Coptic Orthodox.
This Psalm is chanted as the second Canticle or the second Hoos of the Midnight Praises known as <a href="Tasbeha">Tasbeha</a>, a nightly prayer practiced in <a href="Coptic%20Orthodox%20Church">Coptic Orthodox Church</a>es and Monasteries.
Musical Settings.
Verses 1-15 were set by <a href="Roxanna%20Panufnik">Roxanna Panufnik</a> as "Love Endureth" in 2012. "Forever", written by <a href="Chris%20Tomlin">Chris Tomlin</a> in 2001, also draws heavily on this Psalm for its lyrics.
